clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to a famous clock tower known as Big Ben.
It has a river that shares its name with a famous pink Floyd album.
fun_fact: The London Underground is the oldest metro system in the world, opening in 1863.
London has over 170 museums, many of which are free to enter.
trivia: The Tower of London houses the Crown Jewels and is guarded by Beefeaters.
London’s black cabs are required to pass a test called ‘The Knowledge’ to navigate the city’s streets.

clues: This city is famous for its opera house with a unique sail-like design.
It has a harbor bridge that locals affectionately call 'The Coathanger'.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House was designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon and opened in 1973.
Sydney Harbour is the largest natural harbour in the world.
trivia: Sydney is home to the oldest building in Australia, Cadmans Cottage, built in 1816.
The city hosted the 2000 Summer Olympics, which were widely regarded as one of the best ever.

clues: This city is home to an ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
It has a famous fountain where visitors throw coins to ensure their return.
fun_fact: The Colosseum in Rome could hold up to 80,000 spectators and was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
Rome is often called the 'Eternal City' because of its long and continuous history.
trivia: The Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, is located within Rome.
Rome has more fountains than any other city in the world, with over 2,000.

clues: This city is home to the last surviving wonder of the ancient world.
It is located near the Nile River, the longest river in the world.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza, located near Cairo, was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.
Cairo is the largest city in Africa and the Middle East.
trivia: The city is known as 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its abundance of Islamic architecture.
Cairo’s Khan el-Khalili bazaar is one of the oldest markets in the world, dating back to the 14th century.

clues: This city is famous for its annual carnival and samba parades.
It has a massive statue of Christ overlooking the city from a mountain.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
Rio’s Copacabana Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world, stretching over 4 kilometers.
trivia: Rio de Janeiro was the capital of Brazil until 1960 when it was moved to Brasília.
The city’s Maracanã Stadium once held the world record for the highest attendance at a football match.

clues: This city is home to a massive ancient wall that can be seen from space.
It hosted the Summer Olympics in 2008 and the Winter Olympics in 2022.
fun_fact: The Great Wall of China, which stretches near Beijing, is over 21,000 kilometers long.
Beijing’s Forbidden City was the Chinese imperial palace for nearly 500 years.
trivia: Beijing is one of the oldest cities in the world, with a history dating back over 3,000 years.
The city’s Temple of Heaven is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and was used by emperors for annual ceremonies.

clues: This city is located near a flat-topped mountain that is one of the New Seven Wonders of Nature.
It is known for its stunning beaches and vibrant waterfront.
fun_fact: Table Mountain in Cape Town is over 260 million years old and is home to over 2,200 species of plants.
Cape Town was the first city outside Europe to host the World Cup of Football in 2010.
trivia: The Cape of Good Hope, near Cape Town, was once believed to be the southernmost point of Africa.
Cape Town’s Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden is one of the most beautiful gardens in the world.

clues: This city is known for its ornate temples and vibrant street markets.
It has a grand palace that has been the official residence of the kings since 1782.
fun_fact: Bangkok’s full ceremonial name is the longest place name in the world, consisting of 168 characters.
The city is home to the world’s largest solid gold Buddha statue, weighing over 5 tons.
trivia: Bangkok is one of the world’s most visited cities, attracting over 22 million tourists annually.
The city has a floating market where vendors sell goods from their boats.

clues: This city is home to the tallest building in the world.
It has an indoor ski resort located inside a shopping mall.
fun_fact: The Burj Khalifa in Dubai stands at 828 meters, making it the tallest structure globally.
Dubai was once a small fishing village known for pearl diving.
trivia: The city hosts the world’s largest shopping festival every January.
Dubai’s police force uses luxury cars, including Lamborghinis and Ferraris.

clues: This city is also a country and known for its cleanliness and strict laws.
It has an iconic hotel with a rooftop infinity pool overlooking the skyline.
fun_fact: Singapore has over 60 islands within its territory.
The Singapore Flyer is one of the world’s largest observation wheels.
trivia: Chewing gum is banned in Singapore unless it’s for medical purposes.
Singapore’s national symbol is the Merlion, a creature with a lion’s head and a fish’s body.

clues: This city spans two continents: Europe and Asia.
It is famous for a grand mosque with six minarets.
fun_fact: Istanbul was historically known as Byzantium and later Constantinople.
The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world.
trivia: Hagia Sophia has served as a church, mosque, and museum over its long history.
Istanbul is home to more than 3,000 mosques.

clues: This city has a famous square with colorful domed cathedrals.
It is the capital and largest city of its country.
fun_fact: Moscow’s metro system is one of the deepest in the world, with some stations resembling palaces.
The Kremlin in Moscow is both a fortress and the official residence of the President.
trivia: Moscow has more billionaires living in it than any other city in the world.
The city experiences long winters, with snow covering the ground for an average of five months a year.

clues: This city is known for a tall tower with a revolving restaurant.
It is one of the most multicultural cities in the world.
fun_fact: Toronto’s PATH is the world’s largest underground shopping complex.
The CN Tower was the tallest free-standing structure in the world until 2007.
trivia: Toronto is home to the world’s largest Caribbean festival, Caribana.
More than 140 languages are spoken in Toronto.

clues: This city once had a wall that divided it for nearly 30 years.
It is the capital and largest city of Germany.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice, with over 1,700 crossing its waterways.
The Berlin TV Tower is the tallest structure in Germany.
trivia: Berlin’s Museum Island is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.

clues: This city is known as the cradle of Western civilization.
It has a famous ancient hilltop temple called the Parthenon.
fun_fact: Athens is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens in 1896.
trivia: The city is named after Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom.
Athens has more theatrical stages than any other city in the world.

clues: This city is home to a royal palace and the famous N Seoul Tower.
It is known for K-pop and high-tech innovations.
fun_fact: Seoul is the world’s most wired city, with the fastest internet speeds globally.
The city is home to five UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
trivia: The city’s subway system is one of the most efficient and cleanest in the world.
Seoul’s name means “capital city” in Korean.

clues: This city is known as the 'Paris of South America' due to its European-style architecture.
It is the birthplace of tango, a passionate and dramatic dance.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has the widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio, spanning 140 meters.
The city has more bookstores per capita than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Obelisk of Buenos Aires is one of the city’s most iconic landmarks.
Buenos Aires is home to the world’s first metro system in Latin America, opened in 1913.

clues: This city hosts the world’s largest arts festival every August.
It has a historic castle perched on an extinct volcano.
fun_fact: Edinburgh’s Old and New Towns are both UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
The city is considered one of the most haunted places in the world.
trivia: The Harry Potter series was largely written in cafes in Edinburgh.
Edinburgh’s Royal Mile is actually longer than a mile, measuring about 1.12 miles.

clues: This city is known for its centuries-old architecture and rich culture.
It has a famous lake with a legendary turtle and a red bridge.
fun_fact: Hanoi’s Old Quarter has 36 streets, each historically dedicated to a different trade.
Motorbikes are the main mode of transportation, with millions on the roads daily.
trivia: The city’s name means 'Inside the Rivers'.
Hanoi has been the capital of Vietnam for over 1,000 years.

clues: This is the northernmost capital city in the world.
It is known for its colorful buildings and geothermal hot springs.
fun_fact: Reykjavik has no McDonald's—the last one closed in 2009.
The city is powered almost entirely by renewable energy.
trivia: Reykjavik hosts the world’s largest annual whale-watching festival.
The Icelandic language has remained largely unchanged for nearly a millennium.

clues: This city is built on seven hills and offers stunning viewpoints.
It is known for its historic tram system and cobbled streets.
fun_fact: Lisbon’s oldest bookstore, Bertrand, has been operating since 1732.
The city was almost entirely rebuilt after a massive earthquake in 1755.
trivia: Lisbon is home to one of the longest bridges in Europe, the Vasco da Gama Bridge.
The famous Portuguese custard tart, Pastel de Nata, originated here.

clues: This city is surrounded by forests and fjords, making it a nature lover’s paradise.
It is home to the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony every year.
fun_fact: Oslo has one of the highest living standards in the world.
The Viking Ship Museum in Oslo houses well-preserved Viking longships.
trivia: Oslo’s Holmenkollen ski jump has hosted ski competitions for over a century.
The city was previously known as Christiania until 1925.

clues: This city is built on a former Aztec capital and is slowly sinking.
It has one of the largest city squares in the world.
fun_fact: Mexico City has more museums than any other city in the world.
The city sits at an altitude of over 2,200 meters above sea level.
trivia: Mexico City’s Chapultepec Park is twice the size of Central Park in New York.
The Angel of Independence is one of the city’s most famous monuments.

clues: This city is known for its modern design and saunas.
It is one of the northernmost capitals in Europe.
fun_fact: Helsinki has an underground city with shops, tunnels, and even a swimming pool.
The city experiences almost 24 hours of daylight in the summer.
trivia: Helsinki was the World Design Capital in 2012.
The city’s Suomenlinna fortress is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: This city is home to the tallest twin towers in the world.
It has a famous street food scene with a mix of Malay, Chinese, and Indian flavors.
fun_fact: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur were the tallest buildings in the world from 1998 to 2004.
The city’s name means 'Muddy Confluence' in Malay.
trivia: Kuala Lumpur’s Batu Caves feature a giant golden statue of Lord Murugan.
Malaysia’s national dish, Nasi Lemak, is a favorite among locals and tourists alike.

clues: This city is known for classical music, waltzes, and grand palaces.
It was home to famous composers like Mozart and Beethoven.
fun_fact: Vienna has been ranked as the world’s most livable city multiple times.
The city’s famous coffee culture is recognized by UNESCO.
trivia: Vienna’s Schönbrunn Palace has over 1,400 rooms.
The city’s Ferris wheel, Wiener Riesenrad, dates back to 1897.

clues: This city is famous for its medieval astronomical clock.
It is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires' due to its stunning architecture.
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world.
The Charles Bridge in Prague is adorned with 30 statues of saints.
trivia: Prague’s historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The city is home to the oldest active synagogue in Europe.

clues: This city is divided by the Danube River into Buda and Pest.
It is famous for its thermal baths and ruin bars.
fun_fact: Budapest has the largest thermal water cave system in the world.
The city’s Parliament building is one of the tallest in the world.
trivia: Budapest is often called the 'Paris of the East'.
The Chain Bridge was the first permanent bridge across the Danube in Hungary.

clues: This city is known for its canals, cycling culture, and tulips.
It has a museum dedicated to a famous painter who cut off his ear.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more canals than Venice and over 1,200 bridges.
The city is built on wooden poles sunk into marshy ground.
trivia: Amsterdam’s Schiphol Airport is below sea level.
The city is home to the world’s only floating flower market.

clues: This city is spread across 14 islands connected by bridges.
It is known for its Nobel Prize ceremony and Viking history.
fun_fact: Stockholm’s metro system is often called the 'world’s longest art gallery'.
The city has a museum dedicated to the Vasa, a sunken warship.
trivia: Stockholm is one of the cleanest capital cities in the world.
The city’s Old Town, Gamla Stan, dates back to the 13th century.

clues: This city is home to the iconic Little Mermaid statue.
It is known for its cycling culture and sustainable living.
fun_fact: Copenhagen’s Tivoli Gardens is one of the oldest amusement parks in the world.
The city aims to become carbon-neutral by 2025.
trivia: Copenhagen is home to the world’s longest pedestrian street, Strøget.
The city has more Michelin-starred restaurants than any other in Scandinavia.

clues: This city is known for its banking industry and pristine lakes.
It is a hub for art and culture with over 50 museums.
fun_fact: Zurich’s Bahnhofstrasse is one of the most expensive shopping streets in the world.
The city has over 1,200 fountains with drinkable water.
trivia: Zurich is home to the largest church clock face in Europe.
The city hosts one of the largest street parades in Europe every August.

clues: This city is the capital of the European Union and known for its waffles.
It is home to a famous statue of a urinating boy.
fun_fact: Brussels has the highest number of comic strip artists per square kilometer.
The Atomium, a giant steel structure, was built for the 1958 World Expo.
trivia: Brussels is home to over 80 international organizations.
The city’s Grand Place is considered one of the most beautiful squares in Europe.

clues: This city is known for its reconstructed Old Town and royal palaces.
It is home to a famous mermaid statue, the symbol of the city.
fun_fact: Warsaw’s Old Town was rebuilt after being destroyed in World War II.
The city has the tallest building in the European Union, the Varso Tower.
trivia: Warsaw is home to the largest park in Europe, Łazienki Park.
The city’s name means 'belonging to Warsz', a legendary fisherman.

clues: This city is known for its literary history and Guinness beer.
It is home to a famous university with a medieval library.
fun_fact: Dublin’s Temple Bar area is one of the most photographed spots in the city.
The city has more green spaces per capita than most European capitals.
trivia: Dublin is home to the world’s oldest maternity hospital.
The city’s O’Connell Street is one of the widest streets in Europe.

clues: This city is known for its stunning natural scenery and outdoor activities.
It is home to one of the largest urban parks in North America.
fun_fact: Vancouver has the largest Chinatown in Canada.
The city’s Stanley Park is larger than Central Park in New York.
trivia: Vancouver is one of the most ethnically diverse cities in Canada.
The city hosted the 2010 Winter Olympics.

clues: This city is known for its unique architecture by Antoni Gaudí.
It is home to a famous unfinished church, La Sagrada Família.
fun_fact: Barcelona’s La Rambla is one of the most famous streets in Europe.
The city has seven beaches, all of which are man-made.
trivia: Barcelona is home to the largest football stadium in Europe, Camp Nou.

clues: This city is known as the birthplace of the Renaissance.
It is home to a famous statue of David by Michelangelo.
fun_fact: Florence’s Duomo has the largest brick dome ever constructed.

trivia: Florence is the capital of the Tuscany region.
The city’s Ponte Vecchio is the only bridge in Florence that survived World War II.

clues: This city is built on over 100 small islands connected by canals.
It is famous for its gondolas and annual carnival.
fun_fact: Venice’s Grand Canal is the main waterway, lined with historic buildings.
The city is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year.
trivia: Venice has no roads, only canals and footpaths.
The city’s St. Mark’s Basilica is a masterpiece of Byzantine architecture.

clues: This city is known for its vibrant nightlife and art museums.
It is home to a famous royal palace and Retiro Park.
fun_fact: Madrid’s Prado Museum houses one of the finest collections of European art.

trivia: Madrid is the highest capital city in Europe, at 667 meters above sea level.

clues: This city is famous for its Oktoberfest beer festival.

fun_fact: Munich’s Englischer Garten is one of the largest urban parks in the world.

trivia: Munich is the capital of Bavaria, Germany’s largest state.

clues: This city is known for its international organizations and Jet d’Eau fountain.

trivia: Geneva is one of the most expensive cities in the world.

trivia: Osaka is known as the 'Nation’s Kitchen' due to its culinary culture.
The city’s Osaka Castle played a key role in Japan’s unification.
